description: From Middle English launcet, from Old French lancete, a diminutive of lance .

entries.meaning: A sharp, pointed, two-edged surgical instrument used in venesection and for opening abscesses etc.
A small, sterile single-use needle used to draw a drop of blood for testing, as with a glucometer.
(metallurgy) An iron bar used for tapping a melting furnace.
(architecture) A high narrow window, terminating in an arch acutely pointed, often double or triple, common in the first half of the 13th century.
examples: He looked away, into the cavernous space emptying of people. Up in the galleries and behind the choir, the wide window lancets were sheets of black.

verbs.description: lancet (third-person singular simple present lancets, present participle lanceting, simple past and past participle lanceted)
